title: Confession of Israel's Sin
shortSummary: Ezra 9 records a solemn confession by Ezra concerning the intermarriage of the Israelites with surrounding pagan peoples, which violated God's commands. The chapter highlights the seriousness of sin, the need for repentance, and God's mercy in preserving a remnant despite Israel's unfaithfulness.
timeline: c. 458 BC - Post-exilic period during the return from Babylonian captivity under Persian rule

keyCharacters.name: Ezra
keyCharacters.description: A priest and scribe who leads the spiritual restoration of Israel; he receives the report of Israel's sin and offers a heartfelt prayer of confession.

keyCharacters.name: Princes
keyCharacters.description: Leaders of the people who inform Ezra about the intermarriage and the resulting defilement of the holy seed.

definitions.definition: A term referring to the descendants of Israel who are set apart by God and expected to maintain purity from pagan influences.
An ancient expression of grief, mourning, or repentance involving tearing one's clothes as a sign of distress.
The daily evening offering made in the temple, symbolizing worship and intercession to God.
Practices or idols detestable to God, often associated with pagan worship and moral corruption.

outline.heading: Report of Israel’s Sin
outline.description: The princes inform Ezra that the Israelites, including priests and Levites, have intermarried with pagan peoples, defiling the holy seed and breaking God's commands.

outline.heading: Ezra’s Grief and Gathering of the God-fearing
outline.description: Upon hearing the report, Ezra expresses deep sorrow by tearing his clothes and pulling out his hair, then gathers those who fear God to join him in mourning.

outline.heading: Ezra’s Prayer of Confession
outline.description: Ezra prays a humble and honest confession of Israel’s sins, acknowledging their repeated disobedience, pleading for God’s mercy, and recognizing God’s righteousness in preserving a remnant.

application: Confess sin promptly and openly before God, recognizing the seriousness of disobedience.
Avoid compromising your spiritual purity by forming close alliances with influences that lead away from God’s commands.
Seek God’s mercy and restoration through humble prayer when confronted with personal or corporate sin.
Remember that God’s grace preserves a faithful remnant even when judgment is deserved.

keyVerses.text: And when I heard this thing, I rent my garment and my mantle, and plucked off the hair of my head and of my beard, and sat down astonied.
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows Ezra’s deep sorrow and repentance, modeling godly grief over sin.

keyVerses.text: And said, O my God, I am ashamed and blush to lift up my face to thee, my God: for our iniquities are increased over our head, and our trespass is grown up unto the heavens.
keyVerses.significance: Ezra’s prayer acknowledges the overwhelming nature of Israel’s sin and expresses heartfelt shame before God.

keyVerses.text: And now for a little space grace hath been shewed from the LORD our God, to leave us a remnant to escape, and to give us a nail in his holy place, that our God may lighten our eyes, and give us a little reviving in our bondage.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s mercy in preserving a remnant and giving hope despite Israel’s failures.

keyVerses.text: O LORD God of Israel, thou art righteous: for we remain yet escaped, as it is this day: behold, we are before thee in our trespasses: for we cannot stand before thee because of this.
keyVerses.significance: Ezra recognizes God’s righteousness and Israel’s unworthiness, emphasizing the need for grace.
